title: My 11 year old daughter is watching inappropriate videos on YouTube. What should I do? - Quora

response.answer_text: Your 11 year old daughter has unfettered access to YouTube? Hmmm. You need to read this: (Borrowed from YouTube’s own website.) In this setting, your child will only be able to watch videos, channels, and collections that you’ve handpicked. Collections are videos and channels grouped by topics, such as science and music, picked by the YouTube Kids teams or our partners. This setting is available in all countries where YouTube Kids is available. In this setting, your child won’t be able to search for any videos. Tap the Lock icon in the bottom corner of any page in the app.Complete the multiplication problem or read and enter the numbers that appear. Or, enter your custom passcode.Select Settings .Select your child’s profile and enter your parent account password to modify settings.Select “Approved content only” to enable.Review the information in the “Getting Started” pop-up.Select START.Tap the icon on any collection, channel, or video to approve content you’d like to make available to your child.Select DONE in the red box at the bottom of the screen to exit.Note: You can edit the list of collections, channels, and videos you’ve approved at anytime by tapping Manage under the “Approved content only” setting. While you are approving content, you can preview what your child's experience will be like, by tapping PREVIEW. You can also disable “Approved content only” at any time by returning to settings. Here is the link to that guide: Parental controls and settings Here is an article that might help: How to Set Parental Controls on YouTube - RealPlayer and RealTimes Blog If you have a “Real” player. Control your media. You should also set the parental controls on your device. If the boundaries are set, and they keep getting violated, then your 11 year old is going to have to downgrade her phone. There are many parental controls for young people’s phones, but nothing works better than the threat of downgrading to a flip phone. Oh, and spend more time with your 11 year old. It’s a lot of work, but you will thank me, if you just follow that one piece of advice.

Parenting is a little difficult. There are some effective measures that can be undertaken. Make a behavior contract with the child. A behavior contract is a contract signed by the parent and the child. In this you mention the behavior you don't like , you write the date and both parent and child sign this contract. The speciality of this contract is a reward. This reward could be something she likes such as increased play time or reading. A reward that she likes is important and the time period for this contract maybe a week. If she doesn't make the behavioral change then some time from her play time may be reduced. If this doesn't work out Try changing the rewards. The child Should be explained the consequences of bad behavior such as time out or reducing Playtime etc. and the rewards if the child behaves in the appropriate manner. Use praise as well when she does not exhibit that behavior, as you have mentioned when she doesn't watch that content you must praise her. If the child exhibits correct behavior then the child is rewarded. Speak to the child and use this technique. It's interesting and has been used in the United States. A behavior contract has the following important points : Name - parent and child nameDateTime periodRewardConsequences such as time out or reduced playtime.If this fails then try changing rewards. Counsel the child.
